overview: Statutory and abbreviated annual accounts, Company Tax Returns, paying Corporation Tax, corrections, amendments and dealing with losses.
title: Accounts and tax returns for private limited companies

table.body:
At the end of its financial year, your limited company must prepare full ('statutory') annual accounts.

You then use this information to:

- send accounts to Companies House
- send a Company Tax Return to HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) 
- pay Corporation Tax - or tell HMRC that your limited company doesn't owe any

Action | Deadline
- | -
File annual accounts with Companies House | 9 months after your company's financial year ends
File a Company Tax Return | 12 months after your company's financial year ends
Pay Corporation Tax | 9 months and 1 day after your company's financial year ends

^These deadlines are for private limited companies.^

##New and dormant companies

You must take additional steps:

- at the end of [your company's first year](/first-company-accounts-and-return "Your limited company's first annual accounts and Company Tax Return")
- if you [restart a dormant company](/restart-a-dormant-company "Restart a dormant company")

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
After the end of your company's financial year, you must prepare annual accounts - called 'statutory accounts' - from the company's [financial records.](/running-a-limited-company/company-and-accounting-records "Keeping records") 

You must send copies of the statutory accounts to:

- all shareholders
- people who can go to the company's general meetings
- Companies House 
- HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) as part of your Company Tax Return

##How to put together your company's statutory accounts

Statutory accounts must include:

- a 'balance sheet', which shows the value of everything the company owns and is owed on the last day of the financial year
- a 'profit and loss account', which shows how much money the company has received and spent and how much profit it has made
- a director's report about the state of the company
- notes about the accounts, if you want to give more information

A director must sign the balance sheet and their name must be printed on it.

###Accounting standards

Your statutory accounts must meet either:

- International Financial Reporting Standards
- UK Generally Accepted Accounting Practice

$D 
[Download 'Financial Reporting Standards for Small Enterprises' (PDF, 594KB)](http://www.frc.org.uk/Our-Work/Codes-Standards/Accounting-and-Reporting-Policy/FRSSE.aspx "Download 'Financial Reporting Standards for Small Enterprises' (PDF, 594KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

^ You can use accountants or tax advisers to make sure your accounts meet the standards. ^

##Small companies, audit exemption and abbreviated accounts

Your company will be 'small' if it meets 2 of the conditions below: 

- its turnover is less than £6.5 million
- it has less than £3.26 million on its balance sheet
- it has fewer than 50 employees 

If your company meets the legal requirements for 'small' companies, you can:

- send shorter ('abbreviated') accounts to Companies House - this means less information about your company will be publicly available
- use the exemption so your company's accounts [don't need to be audited](/audit-exemption-for-limited-companies "Audit exemption for private limited companies")

###Abbreviated accounts

Abbreviated accounts are the balance sheet from the company's statutory accounts.

The balance sheet must be signed by a director and their name must be printed on it.

^You must still send full 'statutory' accounts to shareholders and to HMRC with your Company Tax Return. ^

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Prepare annual accounts

table.body:
You must send a Company Tax Return online to tell HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) how much Corporation Tax your company needs to pay on its profits. 

The Company Tax Return includes:

* form CT600 
* Corporation Tax calculations (and supporting documents if you're asked for them)
* your [company's statutory accounts](/prepare-and-file-annual-accounts-for-a-limited-company/preparing-annual-accounts "Preparing annual accounts")

##Information you'll need

You'll need to give details including:

- [capital allowances](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/bdotg/action/layer?r.l1=1073858808&r.l2=1086692188&r.l3=1086445219&r.s=tl&topicId=1086384131 "Capital allowances on plant and machinery"){:rel="external"} you want to claim for business assets you've bought
- [gains on assets](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ct/managing/company-tax-return/returns/chargeable-gain.htm "Gains on assets"){:rel="external"} that you've sold for more than they're worth
- [directors' loans](/running-a-limited-company/taking-money-out-of-a-limited-company "Taking money out of a limited company") not repaid at the end of the company's financial year
- repaid directors' loans you want to reclaim tax for 
- [Research and Development Relief](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ct/forms-rates/claims/randd.htm "Research and Development Relief for Corporation Tax"){:rel="external"} you want to claim
- any losses that you 'carry forward' from your previous accounting period

HMRC has guidance on completing your Company Tax Return.

$D [Download 'Company Tax Return Guide' (PDF, 220KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ctsa/ct600-guide-2008.pdf "Company Tax Return guide (PDF, 220KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

##If you made a loss

A loss will reduce your Corporation Tax bill. 

But if you've made losses that you can't claim back in one tax return because they're too large, you can either:

- claim the loss against your previous year's profit - you may get a repayment of Corporation Tax if you do this
- claim the loss in your next financial year

To claim the loss against your previous year's profit either:

- fill in the appropriate box on your Company Tax Return 
- write to your [HMRC Corporation Tax office](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/locator/locator.jsp?type=0 "Find your Corporation Tax office"){:rel="external"} up to 2 years after the end of the financial year when you made the loss

###Repayments

You tell HMRC how to make repayments when you complete your Company Tax Return.

^You might not get a repayment if your company owes HMRC for other taxes.^

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Prepare a Company Tax Return

table.body:
If your accounts and Company Tax Return cover the same period, you can send them to both Companies House and HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) at the same time.

^ If you're sending [your company's first accounts](/accounts-and-company-tax-returns-the-end-of-your-companys-first-year "Your limited company's first accounts and Company Tax Return"), you'll usually need to send more than 1 Company Tax Return. ^

You need your:

- HMRC online Corporation Tax account details
- company registration number
- Companies House online account details
- statutory accounts

##Sending your accounts and Company Tax Return together 

You can send them using [accounting software](http://www.companieshouse.gov.uk/toolsToHelp/accountsSoftware.shtml "Software to file your company accounts and Company Tax Return"){:rel="external"} or HMRC's free online service.

###HMRC's free online service

s1. Log in to your [Corporation Tax Online account.](https://online.hmrc.gov.uk/ "Log in to Corporation Tax Online"){:rel="external"} 
s2. Choose the link 'File a return and accounts'. 
s3. Download the CT600 form and the joint filing accounts template and follow the instructions.


##Sending your Company Tax Return only to HMRC

You must do this online, using either:

- HMRC's [Corporation Tax Online](https://online.hmrc.gov.uk/ "Log in to Corporation Tax Online"){:rel="external"} service
- [accounting software](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/efiling/ctsoft_dev.htm "Corporation Tax software"){:rel="external"} that can send your Company Tax Return to HMRC

##Sending accounts only to Companies House

You can [send your company accounts online](https://ewf.companieshouse.gov.uk/?aa "File your company accounts with Companies House"){:rel="external"}.

##Using accountants or tax advisers to send your returns and accounts

To authorise them, either:

- download and fill in a form 64-8 'Authorising your agent'
- authorise them through the [Corporation Tax Online service](https://online.hmrc.gov.uk/ "Log in to Corporation Tax Online"){:rel="external"}

$D

[Download 'Form 64-8: Authorising your agent' (PDF, 90KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/64-8.pdf "Download 'Form 64-8: Authorising your agent' (PDF, 90KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

To deal with Companies House on your behalf, you must give the accountant or adviser your Companies House authentication code.

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: File your accounts and Company Tax Return
Corrections and amendments

table.body:
##Late accounts for Companies House

If you file your annual accounts late with Companies House, your company could be closed down or directors could be prosecuted.

| Delay | Penalty |
|-|-|
| Up to 1 month | £150 |
| 1 to 3 months | £375 |
| 3 to 6 months | £750 |
| More than 6 months | £1,500 |

The penalties double if your accounts are late 2 years in a row.

##Get an extension

You can apply for an extension if:

- an unforeseen event outside of your control stops you from sending your accounts
- you apply before the filing deadline

Email or write to Companies House, explaining what's happened and how long you'll need to file your accounts.

$C
**Companies House**  
<enquiries@companies-house.gov.uk>
$C

$A
Companies House  
Crown Way  
Cardiff  
CF14 3UZ
$A

##Late Company Tax Return

Time after the deadline | Penalty
- | -
1 day late | £100
3 months late | Another £100
6 months late | HMRC will estimate your company's tax bill and add a penalty of 10% of the estimate
12 months late | Another 10% of the estimated bill 

If your returns are late 3 times in a row, the £100 penalties are increased to £500 each. 

###More than 6 months late

If your Company Tax Return is 6 months late, HMRC will write telling you how much Corporation Tax they think you must pay. This is called a 'tax determination'. You can't appeal against it.

You must either:

- file your Company Tax Return and pay the amount due plus penalties
- pay the bill HMRC sent you straight away

###Appeals

You can appeal to HMRC against a late filing penalty if you have a ['reasonable excuse'](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/online/excuse-missed-deadline.htm "Reasonable excuse for filing an online return late"){:rel="external"}

If you don't have a 'reasonable excuse', you can appeal against a penalty by writing to your company's [Corporation Tax office.](http://search3.openobjects.com/kbroker/hmrc/locator/locator.jsp?type=0 "Corporation Tax offices"){:rel="external"} 

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
